filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions of America a Prophecy Copy O and Europe a Prophecy Copy K.
America Copy O and Europe Copy K are both in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, England. They join copies of America and Europe in the Archive from other printings: America Copies E (1793) and A (1795), and Europe Copies B (1794) and E (1794). Copy M of America, from a c. 1807 printing, and Copy H of Europe (a unique monochrome copy) from a 1795 printing, are forthcoming.
The electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4x5" transparencies; text and images are each fully searchable and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
With the publication of these two titles, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 43 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. They also join our searchable SGML-encoded electronic edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake. With the forthcoming publication of Jerusalem Copy E, the Archive will contain at least one copy of each of Blake's works in illuminated printing and multiple copies of most.
America Copy O is one of fourteen extant copies of America printed by Blake, one of four colored copies, one of two with the full text of Plate 4, one of four without plate e ["Preludium"], and the only copy printed after c. 1807. Europe Copy K is one of nine extant copies printed by Blake, one of only two copies with Plate 3 ["Five windows light the cavern'd Man"], and the only copy printed after 1795. They are extraordinarily beautiful copies, with each impression bordered by one thin line drawn in red ink a few centimeters outside the edge of the image, setting off each page like a miniature painting.
Produced together in 1821 for the painter John Linnell, Blake's young patron, they were printed in orangish-red ink on one side of J. Whatman paper dated 1818, 1819, and 1820, numbered 1-18, and finished in gold, watercolors, and pen and ink in the same style Blake used in c. 1818 and 1821-22, and 1825-27. Works from these sessions include The Book of Thel Copy O, Urizen Copy G, Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies Z and AA, and The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy I, which are in the Archive, and Jerusalem Copy E, Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy P, Milton Copy D, and The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copy G, each of which will soon enter the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old, nude, but muscular man with long hair and beard squats within a circle, perhaps meant to represent the disc of the sun. His hair and beard extend horizontally to the left, as though blown by a strong wind from right to left. His left leg is bent at the knee, with both left knee and left foot prominent. His right leg is kneeling, with the lower leg bent back, on the edge of the circle. He is hunched over and looks down or has his eyes closed; his left arm is extended down. He holds a pair of dividers or compasses in his left hand, with his forefinger spread away from his other fingers. Slight indications of a robe or some sort of drapery appear just right of the figure's left foot. Beams of light emanate from the circle, surrounded by clouds except where the man's arm extends downward. The upper third of the disc is also partly covered with thin clouds in this copy. The figure is very probably Urizen in the act of creating and/or circumscribing the material universe. This design, perhaps Blake's most famous, has also been titled by critics "The Ancient of Days" and "God Creating the Universe."

The horizontal position of the figure's hair and beard suggest a strong wind blowing from right to left.

desc.objtitle: EUROPE a PROPHECY, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The pictorial image is treated as a full-plate design. A giant, scaly snake is coiled just above the imprint. A small crest rises from the top of its head. Its upper body reaches upward in two loops, suggesting a spiral, with its head facing to the right. Its mouth is open; both its long forked tongue and teeth are prominent. Its body extends beyond the lower right margin of the plate and then returns under the imprint, with its tail ending below "Blake" in the imprint. Below the two large coils of its lower body and right and left of "Lambeth" (line 5) in the imprint are some vegetative forms, perhaps leaves; the green wash in the imprint area suggests further vegetation. The background sky includes a cloud, top left, and perhaps thinner, horizontal clouds below "Prophecy" (line 4). The orange and yellow coloring in the upper right corner may suggest a sunrise or sunset. The snake has been identified as the serpent-form of Orc, the personification of revolutionary energy.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A winged insect, perhaps a fly or beetle, soars below the third word in the last line of text (line 25). To the right is a vine with spiky, ivy- like leaves. Spiky beams of light, oddly indicated by dark rather than bright washes, rise from the lower right corner of the plate and along its right margin. The diagonal direction of the washes through the lower half of the text extends the sense of radiance. Blue tinting along the top and left margins indicates sky. Slight rosy tints lower right hint at a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Five windows light the cavern'd Man; thro' one he breathes the air;
Thro' one, hears music of the spheres; thro' one, the eternal vine
Flourishes, that he may recieve the grapes; thro' one can look.
And see small portions of the eternal world that ever groweth;
Thro' one, himself pass out what time he please, but he will not;
For stolen joys are sweet, & bread eaten in secret pleasant.
So sang a Fairy mocking as he sat on a streak'd Tulip,
Thinking none saw him: when he ceas'd I started from the trees:
And caught him in my hat as boys knock down a butterfly.
How know you this said I small Sir? where did you learn this song
Seeing himself in my possession thus he answerd me;
My master, I am yours, command me, for I must obey.
Then tell me, what is the material world, and is it dead?
He laughing answer'd: I will write a book on leaves of flowers,
If you will feed me on love-thoughts, & give me now and then
A cup of sparkling poetic fancies; so when I am tipsie,
I'll sing to you to this soft lute; and shew you all alive
The world, when every particle of dust breathes forth its joy.
I took him home in my warm bosom: as we went along
Wild flowers I gatherd; & he shew'd me each eternal flower:
He laugh'd aloud to see them whimper because they were pluck'd.
They hover'd round me like a cloud of incense: when I came
Into my parlour and sat down, and took my pen to write;
My Fairy sat upon the table, and dictated EUROPE.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures appear in the landscape above the text. A nude male sits crouching in a contracted posture within a cave surrounded at its mouth with large stones. His legs are drawn up and his legs crossed at the ankles. He faces to the left, toward the other figure. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his forearm and index finger on his left hand point up. He grasps a knife or dagger in his right hand. He may be an assassin, contemplating the murder of the figure to the left. This figure on the left is a youthful male wearing tights, a hat, a bundle or backpack on his back, and belts over his chest. He strides forward and to the left. He faces left and holds a walking-stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler. Below his feet is a path or road. Right and left of this walking figure, and above the cave with the assassin, are the leaves of plants or trees. There are also the leaves of plants below the traveler. A rosy tint suggests a sunrise or sunset, top left.

His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left forearm and hand behind his back. He is probably one of Blake's representations of a traveler.
The figure with a dagger crouches within a cave formed of large stones.
The walking figure strides forward on a road or path.
A rosy tint suggests a sunrise or sunset, top left.

Vegetation, probably the leaves of plants or trees, surrounds the walking figure and extends above the cave in which the crouching figure sits. There is also undifferentiated vegetation at the base of the cave on the right and left sides. The large leaves left of the cave may be oak leaves.
The leaves of a plant appear below the traveler.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, we see a human (and apparently male) head, facing forward but with his head turned slightly to the left, with a pained or despairing expression. This head seems to be surrounded tightly by the figure's right arm and snake-like drapery. The ends of this drapery curve over the head and to the left, where it forms two loops. The figure seems to be flying on its large, bat-like wings. Ten birds fly near the figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing. Further to the right, a nude (and bald) male falls head-first. His legs are bent at the knees, with the left leg drawn up near his chest. His arms are raised over his head and bent at the elbows with his hands behind his head. A large weight is attached to his hands or arms, apparently with a single link of a chain that disappears behind his head (because attached to his hands?) This weight apparently pulls him downwards. The spiky forms along the lower margin of the plate suggest vegetation.

Ten birds fly near the bat-winged figure, above him and below and to the right of his left wing.

illustration.illusobjdesc: There is a good deal of interlinear decoration, particularly in the margins of the text. Most consists of vines and leaves, but there are also a few animals. The first letter of the first word, line 3, twists into a spiral vine on the left; it descends with one further loop in the left margin to line 11. A long, wavy vine extends between lines 5 and 6. On it is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 6. To the right of the spider is what may be a very faint suggestion of a caterpillar. Further to the left, under the first word of line 5, is a small form that may be a fly, moth, or butterfly. A vine trails downward from this same first word ("And") in line 5. Just left of the beginning of line 14 is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort. In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word in the last line of text (line 17). In the right margin, another branch of the vine extending between lines 5 and 6 descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. It bears loops, at least two types of leaves, and perhaps some fruit or flowers. A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of this vine (opposite line 5); a worm or caterpillar inches its way across the upper reaches of a large, slender leaf opposite the space between lines 9 and 10. Other branches of this vine extend above the falling figure and intertwine with the large leaf to the right of this same figure. To the right are the ghostly image of two flying birds (more clearly printed in other copies). A separate vine with spiky leaves twists right of lines 6 and 7, growing from the "d" in "thunder." Below one of its tendrils, and just to the right of line 9, is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly. A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 8; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 9. The etching border right of the text has been developed into vaguely vegetative forms. The etching border on the left vaguely resembles the side of a tree trunk or a cliff.

component.illusobjdesc: A butterfly sits on the upper reaches of the vine in the far right margin, right of the space between lines 5 and 6 of the text.
A worm (perhaps an inch worm) or caterpillar rises above the large vine right of the space between lines 9 and 10.

Far to the right of lines 15-16, between the long leaves and the etching border, are the ghostly images of two flying birds. The lower bird is hardly visible at all. They are much more clearly printed in other copies.
The etching border right of the text has been developed into vaguely vegetative forms.
The etching border left of the text has been developed into the side of a tree trunk or a cliff.

A long vine-a branch of the main vine in the right margin-extends horizontally between lines 5 and 6 of the text.
A vine trails downward from the first word ("And") in line 5.
In the bottom left corner of the plate, a vine descends from the first letter of the first word in the last line of text (line 17).

In the right margin of the text, a loopy vine with leaves of at least two types (including very long ones) and perhaps flowers and/or fruit descends from the design above the text all the way to the lower margin. A branch with spiky leaves extends above the falling figure; another branch is intertwined with the long leaf right of this figure.
A vine with three tendrils or branches and perhaps some spiky leaves twists right of lines 6 and 7 of the text, growing from the "d" in "thunder."
A somewhat jagged vine extends horizontally following line 8 of the text; to the right is another vine, growing from the top of the second letter of "of" in line 9.

On the long vine running between lines 5 and 6 of the text is a long-legged spider, just above "other sons" in line 6. To the right of the spider is what may be a very faint suggestion of a caterpillar.
Under the first word of line 5 of the text is a small form that may be a fly, moth, or butterfly.
To the left of the beginning of line 14 in the text is a flying creature, perhaps an insect of some sort, or possibly a flower.
To the right of line 9 of the text is a flying insect, perhaps a beetle or fly.

lg.l: The nameless shadowy female rose from out the breast of Orc:
Her snaky hair brandis in the winds of Enitharmon:The fourth word in line 4 is "brandishing," but the last four letters did not print in this copy.
And thus her voice arose.
O mother Enitharmon wilt thou bring forth other sons?
To cause my name to vanish, that my place may not be found,
For I am faint with travel!
Like the dark cloud disburdend in the day of dismal thunder.
My roots are brandish'd in the heavens, my fruits in earth beneath
Surge, foam, and labour into life, first born & first consum'd!
Consumed and consuming!
Then why shouldst thou accursed mother bring me into life?
I wrap my turban of thick clouds around my lab'ring head:
And fold the sheety waters as a mantle round my limbs,
Yet the red sun and moon,
And all the overflowing stars rain down prolific pains.In Copy K, some of the letters in "stars" printed very lightly.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although containing considerable text, the plate is treated as a full-page design showing four nude males hovering in the sky or on clouds. The two text panels are shaped like clouds; their rosy hue suggests a sunrise or sunset. Upper right, we see a figure from behind with his left leg bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. His hair is very curly. Below is a group of three wrestling figures, all nude and bald. The central figure has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right bent at the knee with his right foot below his genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. This central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand. The figure on the left has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. The wrestler on the right has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. His blue coloring in this copy suggests he may be suffocating. All three figures have caricature-like facial expressions suggesting fear and pain (figures right and left) or desperation and cruelty (central figure). The background darkness suggests a night scene.

component.illusobjdesc: The background darkness surrounding the wrestling figures suggests a night scene. The gold below the center and right figures hints at a cloud (if representational at all).

Upper right, we see a nude male from behind with his left leg bent and his left foot poised on a cloud extending down and to the left. His right leg is extended; he may be rising. We do not see his arms, but his hands clutch his head. This gesture suggests despair. His hair is very curly.
A group of three wrestlers, all nude and bald males, hovers in the sky.

The central bald, nude and muscular male in the group of three wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread, with his left leg extended and his right bent at the knee with his right foot below his prominent genitals. He looks down and to the right. With his right arm he grasps another bald nude around the neck, apparently in an attempt to strangle him. The central figure's left arm is bent at the elbow and he grasps the neck of another bald nude with his left hand.

The figure on the left in the group of three nude and bald male wrestlers hovering in the sky has his legs spread and bent at the knees. He looks up and to the right and tries, with both hands, to release the central male's arm from around his neck. His face expresses pain and terror.

The wrestler on the right in the group of three nude and bald males has his legs spread, with his left leg extended vertically and his right leg bent at the knee. His arms are bent back over his shoulders and grasp the left leg of the central male. His head is bent back as he is being strangled; his face expresses pain and terror. Perhaps his blue coloring in this copy suggests he is suffocating.
The text resides on clouds; their rosy hue suggests a sunrise or sunset. The figure upper right stands on an extension of the clouds constituting the text panels.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vegetative and avian motifs decorate the text. A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 3. A similar vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 14. Fragments of a spiky vine with tendrils or branches, more clearly printed in other copies, hover above "my voice" line 17. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine. Two birds fly above " vig'rous progeny" in line 9, a flock of four birds flies right of line 12, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 14, and a flock of three birds follows line 16.

component.illusobjdesc: Two birds fly above "vig'rous progeny" in line 9 of the text, a flock of four birds flies right of line 12, a single bird soars over "infinite with" in line 14, and a flock of three birds follows line 16.
A vine twists into the left margin from the bottom of the first letter of the first word in line 3 of the text.
A vine connects the last letter of "bind" and the second letter of the next word ("the") in line 14 of the text.
Fragments of a spiky vine with tendrils or branches, more clearly printed in other copies, hover above "my voice" line 17 of the text. The descender of "my" in this same line becomes a twisting vine.

lg.l: Unwilling I look up to heaven! unwilling count the stars!
Sitting in fathomless abyss of my immortal shrine.
I sieze their burning power
And bring forth howling terrors, all devouring fiery kings.
Devouring & devour'd roaming on dark and desolate mountains
In forests of eternal death, shrieking in hollow trees.
Ah mother Enitharmon!
Stamp not with solid form this vig'rous progeny of fires.
I bring forth from my teeming bosom myriads of flames,
And thou dost stamp them with a signet, then they roam abroad
And leave me void as death;
Ah! I am drown'd in shady woe, and visionary joy.
And who shall bind the infinite with an eternal band?
To compass it with swaddling bands? and who shall cherish it
With milk and honey?
I see it smile & I roll inward & my voice is past.
She ceast & rolld her shady clouds
Into the secret place.

objnote.p: The phrase inscribed on the wall is "LORD HAVE MERCY ON US." The "H" of "HAVE" and "Y" of "MERCY" are hidden behind the arms of two of the figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The background of the design is composed of a wall with a large door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US." Left of the door is a standing, and perhaps walking, figure wearing a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at his side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This bellman, as well as the inscription on the door (typical of quarantined houses) can be associated with the theme of plague dominating the design. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out, "Bring out your dead!" Below the bellman on the left are a man and woman. The man, wearing a gown or at least a shirt, appears against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman with his right arm. His face suggests pain or despair; his hair is curly. The gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man. Her hair is long and her right arm is at her side. Her face, with mouth open like her companion’s, expresses despair and perhaps pain, and the limp posture of her body indicates that she may be weak with plague. They may be suffering from the plague. To the right, a gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; like her companions, her posture expresses the pain and despair indicative of the plague. Shadows darken the background in several areas.

component.illusobjdesc: The group of four figures-a bellman and three figures with expressions of pain or despair-indicates that this is a picture of the plague. This is confirmed by the inscription on the door in the background, typical of what was written on the doors of quarantined houses during the great plague of London in 1665.

A standing, and perhaps walking, figure wears a heavy black coat. He faces left, looks down with a worried expression, and wears a large and dark bicorn hat. His left arm is at is side and he holds a large bell in his left hand. This is a bellman, tolling the time. Since his mouth is slightly open, he may be calling out during the plague, "Bring out your dead!"

A male wearing a gown or shirt sits against the left margin of the plate in profile, facing right and down, and perhaps holds the woman to the right with his right arm. His hair is curly and his mouth may be slightly open. His facial expression indicates pain (from disease?) and despair.

A gowned woman sits on the ground, with her upper body propped up by the man to the left. A belt appears just below her breasts. Her hair is long and her right arm is at her side. Her limp posture and her face, with mouth slightly open like her companions, express despair and perhaps pain (of disease?).

A gowned woman with long hair seems to be falling on her knees. Her arms are raised vertically as if in supplication, with the fingers of both hands spread apart. She faces up, with her head bent back; like her companions, her posture indicates pain or despair indicative of disease.
The background of the design is composed of a wall with a large door. The closed door is inscribed "LORD [H]AVE MERC[Y] ON US." Shadows darken the background in several areas.

lg.l: LORD
AVE MERC
ON US

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is an enclosed interior space with a floor and a stone back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate. Above is a large cooking pot with a handle suspended from the top of the fireplace by a rod with a hook at its lower end. Clouds of smoke or steam billow above the pot. In the foreground are three figures. On the left is a gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture. She sits or squats on a small chair or stool (note the curved form far left) with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head is down between her knees; her right foot is prominent. The gowned woman on the right sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her arms are apparently also crossed, with her left hand near her right breast and her right hand near her left breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with a worried or pained expression, perhaps looking at the pot. Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a white cloth spread on the floor. His eyes are closed and he is probably dead. His hair is curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse. Dark wash indicates a shadow on the wall right of the woman on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Dark wash indicates a shadow on the wall to the right of the woman on the right.

A gowned woman, facing right and in an extremely contracted posture, sits or squats on a very small chair or stool (not the curved form far left) with her legs drawn up to her chest and her right arm wrapped around her right knee. Her head his down between her knees; her right foot is prominent.

A gowned woman sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair. Her prominent knees are drawn up toward her chest, with legs crossed. Her arms are apparently also crossed, with her left hand near her right breast and her right hand near her left breast. She wears a necklace of beads and faces up with her neck twisted to the left and with a pained or worried expression on her face. She may be looking at the pot.

Below the woman in the chair is a male child, nude, rigid, and lying supine on a white cloth spread on the floor. His eyes are closed and he is probably dead. His hair is curly. Some interpreters have described this design as a scene of famine, including the contemplation of cannibalism by the woman above the child's corpse.

The setting is an enclosed interior space with a floor and a stone back wall. A fireplace with a grate and an arched top is at the center of the back wall and of the composition. A coal fire burns on the grate.
A large cooking pot hangs by a rod with a hook in its lower end above the grate. Smoke or steam billows above the pot.
The apparently dead child lies on a blanket spread on the floor.
The woman would appear to be sitting or squatting on a very small chair or stool, as indicated by the curved form far left. This shape suggests a neoclassical style in the decorative arts.
The woman sits in an elegant, neoclassical chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Although the plate contains a good deal of text and a great deal of interlinear decoration, the major pictorial motifs—the sky and the two largest figures—constitute a full- plate design. The three text panels are shaped like, and may represent, clouds floating in the sky. The largest figure, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist. Her long, curled hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (Plate 4, line 3) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (Plate 4, line 14). Below her cascading hair is a nude, youthful male in a contracted posture. He seems confined by the circle in which he sits. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. It may be a planet. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. He faces forward. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 5), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (Plate 5, line 9). The other motifs on this plate, including many human figures, will be treated as interlinear designs.

component.illusobjdesc: The largest figure on the plate, hovering horizontally in the air just below the heading, is a gowned female. Her body is twisted, facing forward below the waist and facing down above the waist. The hem of her garment forms a snake-like tail. Her long, curled hair cascades over (and hence obscures) her face. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are clasped behind her head. She has large wings, and thus may be an angel. More specifically, in the context of this poem, she has been identified as Enitharmon, a nature goddess of fallen time and space, and as the "nameless shadowy female" (Plate 4, line 3) who wraps a "turban of thick clouds" around her "lab'ring head" (Plate 4, line 14).

A nude, youthful male in a very contracted posture sits within a circle. This circle may be meant to represent a globe; it has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. His legs are bent at the knees and drawn up to his chest; his arms are bent at the elbows with his hands, formed into fists, against his cheeks just below his eyes. Flames surround him within the globe. This may be Orc, the spirit of revolution here confined, the "secret child" (of Enitharmon?) mentioned on the plate (line 5), or one of Enitharmon's "vig'rous progeny of fires" (Plate 5, line 9).

A figure squats or sits within a circle which may be meant to represent a globe. It has been described as a comet, although there is no tail. Hence, this may be a planet. Flames surround the figure within the globe.
The three text panels are shaped like, and may be intended to represent, clouds. Rosy tinting suggests a sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The heading is surrounded by several figures and vegetative motifs. The figures, particularly the larger ones, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 8) of Enitharmon referred to on the plate. The lower left corner of "A" (in "A Prophecy" [lines 2-3]) grows into a long vine with branches. Standing on this vine, near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure facing forward. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female. On the right foot of "A" is a tree, possibly a palm, with branches that bend downward. This tree is also slightly anthropomorphic in this copy. To the left of the "A" and slightly below it is a male embracing a female. Both hover in the air, with the male on the right and facing to the left. Both have long hair and appear nude, although the woman has a long, snake-like tail of drapery extending from her right leg. The man's body is twisted into a curve, seen from behind. His left arm is raised horizontally and embraces the woman's waist. His right leg is extended horizontally. We also see the woman from behind, with her body twisted into a curve matching the man's. Both her arms are raised horizontally, with her head facing down. These gestures suggest that she is trying to escape from the man. In contrast, the couple right of the letter "A" is embracing mutually and appear to be kissing. The winged male (an angel?) hovers horizontally in the air, with his arms raised at 45 degrees to embrace the woman who hovers vertically. She too is winged and may be an angel. Her legs are bent back and her arms raised at 135 degrees to embrace her companion. He faces down and to the left; she faces up and to the right. Below the "A" is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline. Other cloud outlines extend to the upper right and below "Prophecy" in the heading. On the right, below a cloud outline and above the last letter of "Prophecy," two nude figures seen from behind soar in the sky, left arms raised horizontally and right arms raised at 135 degrees. The letters of "Prophecy" are well decorated with human figures and vines. Proceeding from left to right, these include a vine with leaves or lily-like flowers intertwined with the first letter and extending to the second. A figure stands on the foot of the vertical of the "R" and faces to the left with arms raised vertically. Above this figure is a small form that may be a descending child or infant, arms stretched downward toward the adult. The right foot of the "R" bears a very small seated figure, hunched over and facing to the right. The letter "O" has two vines with lily-like flowers. Standing within the "O" is a figure facing forward and with left arm raised horizontally to hold a shepherd's crook. To the right of this shepherd is a small flock of sheep. Three vines, or perhaps flames, spring from the foot of the second "P." A vine, perhaps with a few leaves, is intertwined with the next three letters ("HEC"). The final vine in this group springs from the foot of the final letter and forms a spiral above and to the right of the letter. This "Y" also bears three human figures. One, seen from behind and with legs spread and arms raised vertically, seems to be climbing, with the right foot on the foot of the "Y" and the left foot on the "C." Above, standing on the top left end of the "Y," is a figure facing left who seems to lean against a pole, with one or both arms raised vertically, or possibly a somewhat larger figure walking to the left. Finally, the first bend in the vine growing from the right side of the final letter bears a seated figure facing right, with back slightly hunched over and right arm extended to the right knee. This figure holds a book or tablet and is probably reading. Two flames, or perhaps a flame-like plant, spring from the foot of the "Y" on its right side.

component.illusobjdesc: The human figures surrounding the heading, particularly the four largest figures, may be the "sons & daughters" (line 8) of Enitharmon referred to on the plate.

Standing on the vine springing from the lower left of the letter "A" (line 2), near the left foot of the letter, is a human figure facing forward. His or her arms, raised vertically, grow into limbs of a tree that bend downwards, as with a willow. The motif suggests the classical myth of Daphne and her vegetating metamorphosis. This parallel suggests that the figure is female.

A nude male, hovering in the air, embraces a female with his left arm around her waist. We see him from behind, but his body is twisted into a curve. His hair is long; his right leg is extended horizontally to the left. He faces left.

A nude female with long hair, facing down and to the left, hovers in the air. She is embraced around the waist by the male to the right. We see her from behind, with her body twisted into a curve like the male's. Although apparently nude from the waist up, a long, snake-like tail of drapery extends from her right leg. Her arms are raised horizontally to the right. This gesture, as well as her head position, suggest that she is trying to flee from the male.

A nude male hovers horizontally and reaches down, with his arms at 45 degrees, to embrace the female below and to the left. His large wings suggest he may be an angel. He faces down and to the left and may be kissing the female. His hair may be curly.

A nude female hovers in the air. Her large wings suggest she may be an angel. She reaches up with her arms at 135 degrees to embrace the male hovering horizontally to the right. Her legs are slightly bent. She faces up and to the right and may be kissing the male.

Below the "A" (line 2) of the heading is a hunched over, and apparently gowned, figure facing to the left. This extremely contracted figure, with his or her upper body and head bent down to touch the upper legs, sits on a cloud outline.
A small figure stands, facing left, on the foot of the letter "R" in "Prophecy" (line 3). The figure, probably male, has his arms raised vertically, perhaps to catch the small figure above.

Just above the figure standing on the left foot of the letter "R" in "Prophecy" (line 3) is a very small human form, probably a child or infant. This tiny figure descends head-first toward the adult below, with arms reaching downward.
A very small figure sits on the right foot of the letter "R" in "Prophecy" (line 3). The figure faces right and is slightly hunched over.

A figure, probably male, stands within the "O" of "Prophecy" (line 3). He faces forward with his left arm raised horizontally. He holds a shepherd's crook in his left hand. Given the crook and the flock of sheep to the right, the figure is almost certainly a shepherd.

A figure, probably male and seen from behind, climbs between the "C" and "Y" of "Prophecy" (line 3). His legs are spread, with his left foot poised on the "C" and his right foot just touching the foot of the "Y." He reaches up vertically with both arms to hold the left diagonal of the "Y."

A very small figure, probably male, stands on top of the left diagonal of the "Y" in "Prophecy" (line 3). He is probably facing to the left or facing away and leans against a pole, with one or perhaps both arms raised vertically. His legs may be spread apart. Alternatively, this may be a somewhat larger figure walking to the left.
The small figure standing on top of the left diagonal of the "Y" of "Prophecy" (line 3) may be leaning against a pole.

A small figure, probably gowned and male, sits on the vine extending from the "Y" of "Prophecy" (line 3). He faces to the right, with his upper body hunched over and his right arm extended at 45 degrees to his knees. He holds, and seems to be reading, a book or tablet.
The small figure sitting on the vine extending from the "Y" of "Prophecy" (line 3) would appear to be holding a book or tablet.

Two figures hover in, or fly through, the air above the "Y" of "PROPHECY" (line 3). Both are nude; the upper figure appears to be male, while the lower figure seems to be female. Both have their left arms raised horizontally and right arms raised at 135 degrees, and both may be holding something in their right hands. The male’s body is twisted, and his left leg crosses in front of his right leg. The female’s right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep rests within the "O" of "Prophecy" (line 3), just to the right of their shepherd.
Flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the second "P" of "Prophecy" (line 3) on its right side.
Two flames, or perhaps flame-like plants, spring from the foot of the "Y" of "Prophecy" (line 3) on its right side.

The outlines of clouds extend above "Prophecy" (line 3) from the "O" to the upper right corner of the plate; one cloud outline descends between the second "P" and "H" of the word and extends below the word to the "R."
A vine, perhaps with leaves, extends to the left from the left foot of "A" (line 2) in the heading.
The raised arms of the figure standing on the left foot of "A" (line 2) in the heading vegetate into branches that arch downward. This may be a willow.
A small tree with arching branches, perhaps a palm, grows from the right foot of "A" (line 2) in the heading. This tree is slightly anthropomorphic in this copy.

A vine is intertwined with the first letter of "Prophecy" (line 3) in the heading. There are leaves or perhaps lily-like flowers at its left end; its right end curls behind the foot of the next letter ("R").

A vine with lily-like flowers is intertwined with the left side of the "O" of "Prophecy" (line 3). A separate vine, or the other end of the same vine, grows up the right side of the same letter. It too bears lily-like flowers.
A vine with one loop and a few leaves is intertwined with the letters "HEC" of "Prophecy" (line 3).
A vine, with a spiral upper right, grows from the right side of the foot of "Y" of "Prophecy" (line 3).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The cloud-like text panel containing lines 4-7 of the text includes three human figures, birds, and some vines. A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 4 and turns to the right over the first line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops. To the right of the second loop sits a gowned and apparently female figure. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees and extended to the right. Above her and to the left is a flock of five birds. Two figures hover in the air right of line 4. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. To the right is a (probably nude and male) figure also hovering and seen from behind. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it. To the right of this figure, and above "eternal" in line 6, is a vine. Another vine, with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 7. To the right of this line are two birds, flying upward on extended wings.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably female and wearing a gown, sits on the vine above "deep of" in line 4 of the text. Her body faces to the left, but her head seems to be turned to the right so that we see her head and shoulders from behind. Her left arm extends downward to her knee; her right arm is raised at about 135 degrees.

Two figures hover in the air right of line 4 of the text. The gowned figure on the left is probably a female; we see her from behind with one arm raised horizontally and the other at 135 degrees. The hem of her gown forms a twisting tail.

To the right of line 4, and right of the hovering female figure, is a (probably nude and male) figure also hovering and seen from behind. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee. He holds, and apparently plays, a horn with one loop in it.
The figure hovering above "eternal" (line 6) holds, and presumably plays, a horn with one loop in it.
A flock of five birds flies on extended wings above the vine extending horizontally above line 4 of the text.
Two birds fly upwards on extended wings right of line 7 of the text.
A vine with two loops extends from the first word of line 4 of the text and turns to the right over this same line. On it may be a single leaf or flower between the two loops.
A vine curls above "eternal" in line 6 of the text.
A vine, perhaps with leaves at its lower end, extends from the last letter of the last word ("abodes") in line 7 of the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four figures, birds, a cloud outline, and a vine decorate the third cloud-like text panel containing lines 8-17 of the text. A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 8 and extends above the line to the word "her." A much smaller vine or single leaf grows from the vertical of the last letter in this line. Just above the first word ("Then"), a nude figure (probably male) lies supine on this vine. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body. The figure above may be gowned (note the slight suggestion of trailing drapery) and of uncertain gender. This figure's legs are spread and one arm (the left?) is raised vertically. The figure may be rising in the air. To the right, above "Enitharmon" in line 8, is a flying bird. Another two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 12. A cloud outline (or perhaps the surface of the earth?) below and to the right of the birds bears a figure crawling to the right on all fours. Further to the right, another figure, perhaps female, stands and leans to the left against the cloud outline. Her legs are crossed; she may be wearing tights in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude figure, probably male, lies supine on the vine above the first word ("Then") in line 8 of the text. One leg is extended, the other bent at the knee. The figure faces up; his arms are raised at 135 degrees relative to his body.

A figure, facing left, hovers above the first letter of "Enitharmon" in line 8 of the text. This figure, of uncertain gender, has his or her (left?) arm raised vertically and legs spread. The figure may be gowned (note the slight suggestion of a tail of drapery) and rising.
A figure crawls to the right on all fours along the cloud outline (or surface of the earth?) above the last word ("rest") in line 13 of the text. The figure may be gowned.

A figure, probably female and possibly wearing tights in this copy, stands and leans to the left against a cloud outline. Her upper body, twisted to the left, is braced against the cloud with her left arm; her legs are crossed.
A bird flies upward on extended wings above the middle letters of "Enitharmon" (and above the vine), line 8 of the text.
Two birds fly on extended wings above the last word ("come") in line 12 of the text.
A vine loops upward from the first letter of the first word in line 8 and extends above the line to the word "her."
The vertical of the final letter of "around," the last word in line 8 of the text, becomes a vine arching over the word. It may terminate in a leaf.
A cloud outline-or possibly the surface of the ground-extends between lines 11 and 12 of the text.

lg.l: The deep of winter came;
What time the secret child,
Descended thro' the orient gates of the eternal day;
War ceas'd, & all the troops like shadows fled
to their abodes.
Then Enitharmon saw her sons & daughters rise around.
Like pearly clouds they meet together in the crystal house:
And Los. possessor of the moon, joy'd in the peaceful night:
Thus speaking while his num'rous sons shook their bright fiery wings
Again the night is come
That strong Urthona takes his rest,
And Urizen unloos'd from chains
Glows like a meteor in the distant north
Stretch forth your hands and strike the elemental strings!
Awake the thunders of the deep,

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design below the text is dominated by two large figures and five smaller ones. A nude and youthful male lies prone on grassy ground. He faces down, with his arms bent and his head resting on them. Only part of his left arm and right hand are visible. His hair is curly and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc. Above him, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended and her right bent at the knee under her torso. Her arms are extended horizontally and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. She is probably Enitharmon. The five much smaller figures above may be her sons and daughters. In the left corner of the design, just below the text, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread, body twisted to the left. The gender of this figure is uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion. Similar exhaustion is indicated by the nude figure to the right. This figure is probably female and also lies supine on a cloud. Her body is bent back, with her head, right arm, and right leg dangling downward. Above and to the right is another nude female, lying supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee. Further to the right is an embracing couple hovering in the air, with the woman on the right. They may be kissing. The nude male, facing right, has his legs spread and his right arm raised horizontally. The female, facing left, is gowned. Her legs are spread apart. Her long hair may be gathered into a bun.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude and youthful male lies prone on grassy ground. He faces down, with his arms bent and his head resting on them. Only part of his left arm and right hand are visible. His hair is curly and a halo of fire surrounds his head. This is probably the youthful Orc.

Above the youthful male lying prone, a nude female with long, flame-like hair kneels on a cloud and leans dramatically to the left. Her left leg is extended, her right bent at the knee and drawn up under her torso. Her arms are extended horizontally and she holds, and apparently lifts with both hands, a cloak, blanket, or heavy drapery to uncover the youth below, at whom she is looking. In this copy, a piece of the cloth extends behind her head and right knee. She is probably Enitharmon.
Five nude figures fill the sky just below the text. These may be the sons and daughters of Enitharmon.

In the left corner of the design, just below the text, we see a nude figure lying supine on a cloud with legs bent and spread. The gender of this figure is uncertain; his or her posture suggests erotic exhaustion.
A nude figure, probably female, lies supine on a cloud. Her posture suggests erotic exhaustion, with her head bent back and her right arm and right leg dangling downward.

A nude female lies supine on a cloud with her upper body propped up with her bent right arm. She faces right and has long hair. Her right leg is extended to the right and her left leg bent at the knee.
A nude male, facing right, embraces a female and perhaps kisses her. He hovers in the air, with legs spread. His right arm is raised horizontally.

A gowned female, facing left, hovers in the air and apparently embraces—and perhaps kisses—the male to the left. Her legs are spread apart and a gown or piece of drapery curves over her left leg, forming a curling tail. Her long hair may be twisted into a bun.
The green coloring of the ground and a few jagged lines indicate grass.

The large female figure, and the three smaller figures above her on the left, lie or kneel on clouds. The clouds supporting the figures second and third from the left look almost like large stones. The rosy tinting may be caused by the halo of fire around Orc's head-or possibly a sunrise or sunset (on the left?).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The text panel is shaped like, and may represent, a cloud floating in the sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is well decorated with vines, one fairly large human figure, and animals. Right of lines 8-11 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down but with his face turned upward, and his arms raised and wrapped around his head. Right of line 5 are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird, a winged insect (perhaps a beetle or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird. Another winged creature, perhaps a bird, flies right of lines 8-9. Left and right of this creature are two vines; the vine on the right is worm-like. A vine below line 9 includes one loop and a grain tassel on its right end. A grasshopper or locust stands on this vine, facing right. Three winged insects fly above the grain tassel. Another vine appears further to the right, with at least one leaf and three loops. Vines, or extensions of a cloud outline, extend below line 15. A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 18 and a vine grows from the "h" of the next word ("Enitharmon"). The etching border on the left has been developed into vegetative forms.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of lines 8-11 of the text, a nude male seems to be falling through the air. His body is twisted dramatically at the waist, with his legs together, his head down but with his face turned upward, and his arms bent upward and wrapped around (but not quite touching) his head.
Right of line 5 of the text are four flying creatures. Reading left to right, these are a bird, a winged insect (perhaps a beetle or moth), a butterfly or moth, and a bird.
A winged creature, perhaps a bird or insect, flies right of lines 8-9 of the text.
A grasshopper or locust sits, facing right, on the vine above line 11 of the text.
Three flying insects, perhaps flies or moths, appear below "nights of" in line 10 of the text.
A bird flies on extended wings above the first word ("Then") in line 18 of the text.
Two vines appear right of lines 8-9 of the text. The vine on the right is worm-like.
A vine with one loop and a grain tassel at its right end appears between lines 10 and 11 of the text.
A vine with three loops and one leaf wends its way between lines 10 and 11 of the text, left of the descending figure.
The etching border on the left has been developed into vegetative forms.
An extension of a cloud outline between lines 15 and 16 of the text takes on the appearance of a vine.
A vine grows from the "t" of "Enitharmon," the second word in line 18 of the text.

lg.l: The shrill winds wake!
Till all the sons of Urizen look out and envy Los:
Sieze all the spirits of life and bind
Their warbling joys to our loud strings
Bind all the nourishing sweets of earthIn Copy K, the second "s" in "sweets" printed very lightly.
To give us bliss, that we may drink the sparkling wine of Los
And let us laugh at war,
Despising toil and care.
Because the days and nights of joy. in lucky hours renew.
Arise O Orc from thy deep den,
First born of Enitharmon rise!
And we will crown thy head with garlands of the ruddy vine;
For now thou art bound;
And I may see thee in the hour of bliss, my eldest born.
The horrent Demon rose, surrounded with red stars of fire,
Whirling about in furious circles round the immortal fiend.
Then Enitharmon down descended into his red light,
And thus her voice rose to her children, the distant heavens reply.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Above the text, a scaly male stands between two female angels. He stands in a slightly contrapposto posture, facing forward and with his legs spread apart. He wears a spiky crown. His right arm is slightly bent, with his right hand behind his right thigh. He holds a large sword, with its point behind his left leg, in his left hand. The scales may represent armor, although they extend over his face. This may be Rintrah, as a personification of military wrath, referred to in the text on this plate. Both angels have large wings. The angel on the left has her arms folded over her chest and looks to the right. The angel on the right has her hands together, as if in prayer or supplication, and looks to the left. Both wear long gowns and have sun-like halos. Beams of light, apparently emanating from the halos, descend at a 45 degree angle right and left of the figures. The vegetative motifs on which the figures stand are described as interlinear designs.

component.illusobjdesc: Above the text, a scaly male stands between two female angels. He stands in a slightly contrapposto posture, facing forward and with legs spread apart. He wears a spiky crown. His right arm is slightly bent, with his right hand behind his right thigh. He holds a large sword, with its point behind his left leg, in his left hand. The scales may represent armor, although they extend over his face. This may be Rintrah, as a personification of military wrath, referred to in the text on this plate.
A gowned, female angel stands on the left of the male figure. She has large wings, looks to the right, and has her arms folded over her chest. Her head is backed by a sun-like halo.

A gowned, female angel stands on the right of the male figure. She has large wings, looks to the left, and has her hands together as if in prayer or supplication. Her head is backed by a sun-like halo.
The central figure in the group of three holds a large sword in his left hand.
Beams of light, apparently emanating from the halos of the angels, descend at a 45 degree angle right and left of the angels.

lg.l: Now comes the night of Enitharmons joy,
Who shall I call? Who shall I send?
That Woman, lovely Woman! may have dominion?
Arise O Rintrah thee I call! & Palamabron thee!
Go! tell the human race that Womans love is Sin:
That an Eternal life awaits the worms of sixty winters
In an allegorical abode where existence hath never come:
Forbid all Joy, & from her childhood shall the little female
Spread nets in every secret path.
My weary eyelids draw towards the evening, my bliss is yet but new

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text panel, shaped like a cloud, are two figures in a cloudy, perhaps stormy, environment. A gowned and elderly male with long hair and beard stands on the right facing to the left. His arms are raised horizontally, with palms outward (that is, facing to the left). His worried expression, staring eyes, and arm gesture suggest that he is afraid of some unpictured presence to the left. He may be Albion's Angel, frightened at the prospect of coming revolution. A gowned woman kneels on the ground before the old man, with right leg extended backward and left leg bent at the knee. Her body is bent forward and her head is down. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she embraces the old man around his legs. Her long hair cascades below her right upper arm. She may be supplicating the man for help. The background for the figures is filled with clouds. The green coloring of the ground suggests grass. Some of the clouds may also represent smoke. This may be a night scene, illuminated only by distant fires or a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Arise O Rintrah eldest born: second to none but Orc:
O lion Rintrah raise thy fury from thy forests black;
Bring Palamabron horned priest, skipping upon the mountains;
And silent Elynittria the silver bowed queen:
Rintrah where hast thou hid thy bride:
Weeps she in desart shades?
Alas my Rintrah! bring the lovely jealous Ocalythron.
Arise my son! bring all thy brethren O thou king of fire.
Prince of the sun I see thee with thy innumerable race:
Thick as the summer stars:
But each ramping his golden mane shakes.
And thine eyes rejoice because of strength O Rintrah furious king

illustration.illusobjdesc: Grain stems grow from the lower left corner of the plate and coil upward into the large design above the text. Several vines, at least one of which bears ivy-like leaves, are intertwined with the lower reaches of the stems, below and right of the text. In this copy, the etching border left of the text has been developed into a vegetative form, probably more grain stems. The stems form a large "C" curve above the text and end near the right margin in grain tassels. Two figures appear within this "C" curve. The nude female, on the left, is seen from behind; her long hair is formed into a loose bun. She hovers in the air, with her right leg extended and her left bent at the knee. Her body and head are twisted to the right. She holds in her raised right hand, and no doubt plays, a large, coiled horn or trumpet. The black and orange spots of blight covering the grain appear to emanate from the trumpet and the one her male companion plays. He is also nude, seen from behind, and has his body twisted dramatically to the right. His left leg is extended, his right bent at the knee as he hovers in the air. He holds his coiled horn or trumpet with his left hand. Both arms are raised horizontally. His hair is curly. Blue tinting upper right and left indicates sky.

lg.l: Enitharmon slept,
Eighteen hundred years: Man was a Dream!
The night of Nature and their harps unstrung:
She slept in middle of her nightly song.
Eighteen hundred years, a female dream!
Shadows of men in fleeting bands upon the winds:
Divide the heavens of Europe:
Till Albions Angel smitten with his own plagues fled with his bands
The cloud bears hard on Albions shore:
Fill'd with immortal demons of futurity:
In council gather the smitten Angels of Albion
The cloud bears hard upon the council house; down rushing
On the heads of Albions Angels.
One hour they lay buried beneath the ruins of that hall;
But as the stars rise from the salt lake they arise in pain,
In troubled mists o'erclouded by the terrors of strugling times,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A snake extends below the text, up the left margin, and above the text. Its tail is in the lower margin; its body, in the left margin, has seven loops or coils suggesting, if not quite forming, a spiral; its head rises above the text. Its mouth is open; its tongue merges with the halo of flames surrounding its crested head. The mottled patterns on the snake's body suggest scales. This is probably the serpent-form of Orc, the spirit of revolution, although a more immediate textual context on this plate appears in line 18: "Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent".

lg.l: (following
In thoughts perturb'd they rose from the bright ruins silent
The fiery King, who sought his ancient temple serpent-form'd
That stretches out its shady length along the Island white.
Round him roll'd his clouds of war; silent the Angel went,
Along the infinite shores of Thames to golden Verulam.
There stand the venerable porches that high-towering rear
Their oak-surrounded pillars, form'd of massy stones, uncut
With tool; stones precious; such eternal in the heavens,
Of colours twelve, few known on earth, give light in the opake.
Plac'd in the order of the stars, when the five senses whelm'd
In deluge o'er the earth-born man; then turn'd the fluxile eyes
Into two stationary orbs, concentrating all things.
The ever-varying spiral ascents to the heavens of heavens
Were bended downward; and the nostrils golden gates shut
Turn'd outward, barr'd and petrify'd against the infinite.
Thought chang'd the infinite to a serpent; that which pitieth:
To a devouring flame; and man fled from its face and hid
In forests of night; then all the eternal forests were divided
Into earths rolling in circles of space, that like an ocean
rush'd
And overwhelmed all except this finite wall of flesh.
Then was the serpent temple form'd, image of infinite
Shut up in finite revolutions, and man became an Angel;
Heaven a mighty circle turning: God a tyrant crown'd.
Now arriv'd the ancient Guardian at the southern porch.
That planted thick with trees of blackest leaf, & in a vale
Obscure, inclos'd the Stone of Night; oblique it stood, o'erhung
With purple flowers and berries red; image of that sweet south,
Once open to the heavens and elevated on the human neck,
Now overgrown with hair and coverd with a stony roof, (feet
Downward 'tis sunk beneath th' attractive north, that round the
A raging whirlpool draws the dizzy enquirer to his grave.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned male sits on a throne-like chair, the chair in turn resting on a cloud. He faces forward and wears the triple-crown of a Pope. His face, however, may be a caricature of George III. He holds on his lap an open book. Large, bat- like wings extend from behind his arms. The back of his chair resembles the facade of a gothic church, with arches and spires right and left. In some copies, the figure appears to have bat-like ears that merge with the pointed arches on the throne behind him. The coloring in Copy K suggests that the figure has human ears. His gown between his legs seems to contain embroidered pictures of perhaps four gowned and standing figures. Below this Pope, and below the cloud, are two female angels, right and left, with large wings. Both have long hair, are gowned, bow and look down, and have one arm extended at 45 degrees. Each has a halo around her head and holds in her extended hand a scepter or staff with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower termination. Snake-like tails project from beneath the angels' gowns. The angel on the right looks sharply down or has her eyes closed.

A snake-like and scaly tail extends from the hem of her gown.

She hold in her left hand a staff or scepter with a fleur-de-lis point at its lower termination. A snake-like, scaly tail extends from the hem of her gown.
The crowned male sits in a chair. Its back resembles the facade of a Gothic church, with arches and spires right and left.
The chair in which the male sits is placed on a cloud.

lg.l: Albions Angel rose upon the Stone of Night,
He saw Urizen on the Atlantic:
And his brazen Book,
That Kings & Priests had copied on Earth
Expanded from North to South.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration, dominated by spider webs, extends along the right margin, extends between lines 21 and 22 of the text, and fills the bottom margin of the plate. Top right is a curtain-like form that apparently represents a web. At least five spiders appear on the web: right of lines 15-17, right of line 20, in a dense web below the first word ("Fled") in line 21, above "wide" in line 24, and right of lines 29-31 (dangling on a single thread). What may be a sixth spider appears above "& louder" at the end of line 15. A great many insects appear in the design, although some are simply suggested by little more than dots. The larger and more identifiable insects are a winged insect right of lines 11-13, possibly a fly or butterfly further to the right and just above the large spider, four flies (two very small) right of lines 15-17, a large winged insect (a beetle?) right of line 21 and half-way to the right margin, a caterpillar below and to the left of this last insect, another winged fly or beetle above and to the right of the spider between lines 21 and 22, and a large fly or beetle (and a cluster of very small insects) below "he drag'd" in line 21. The landscape below the text is filled with heavy vegetation, including low plants with large leaves, a tuft grass(?) between them, and a vine or plant with four large leaves in the lower right corner. Just to the left is a nude figure, of uncertain gender, sitting on the ground and completely covered by a fine net or web. The legs are bent at the knees and the body is twisted so that the figure faces forward. The head is bent back and she or he looks up. The upper body is braced up on the elbows. The hands are held together in an attitude of supplication or prayer. The mouth would appear to be slightly open. This figure may relate to the image of "every man bound" (line 27).

lg.l: And the clouds & fires pale rolld round in the night of EnitharmonIn Copy K, the "s" in "clouds" printed very lightly.
Round Albions cliffs & Londons walls; still Enitharmon slept:
Rolling volumes of grey mist involve Churches, Palaces, Towers:
For Urizen unclaspd his Book! feeding his soul with pity
The youth of England hid in gloom curse the paind heavens; compell'd
Into the deadly night to see the form of Albions Angel
Their parents brought them forth & aged ignorance preaches canting.
On a vast rock, perciev'd by those senses that are clos'd from thought:
Bleak, dark, abrupt, it stands & overshadows London city
They saw his boney feet on the rock, the flesh consum'd in flames:
They saw the Serpent temple lifted above, shadowing the Island white:
They heard the voice of Albions Angel howling in flames of Orc.
Seeking the trump of the last doom
Above the rest the howl was heard from Westminster louder & louder;
The Guardian of the secret codes forsook his ancient mansion,
Driven out by the flames of Orc; his furr'd robes & false locks
Adhered and grew one with his flesh, and nerves & veins shot thro' them
With dismal torment sick hanging upon the wind: he fled
Groveling along Great George Street thro' the Park gate; all the soldiers
Fled from his sight: he drag'd his torments to the wilderness.
Thus was the howl thro Europe!
For Orc rejoic'd to hear the howling shadows
But Palamabron shot his lightnings trenching down his wide back
And Rintrah hung with all his legions in the nether deep
Enitharmon laugh'd in her sleep to see (O womans triumph)
Every house a den, every man bound; the shadows are filld
With spectres, and the windows wove over with curses of iron:
Over the doors Thou shalt not; & over the chimneys Fear is written:
With bands of iron round their necks, fasten'd into the walls
The citizens: in leaden gyves the inhabitants of suburbs
Walk heavy: soft and bent are the bones of villagers
Between the clouds of Urizen the flames of Orc roll heavy
Around the limbs of Albions Guardian. his flesh consuming,
Howlings & hissings. shrieks & groans. & voices of despair
Arise around him in the cloudy
Heavens of Albion, Furious

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting is a stone prison cell with stone stairs rising on the right. A prisoner, lower left, has shackles on both ankles; the shackles are in turn attached to the stone floor with two heavy chains. The prisoner is a nude male with curly hair who sits on a stone ledge. His prominent knees are drawn up to his chest and his legs crossed at the ankles. His neck is twisted to the right; his head is back and he seems to look up at the figure on the right. His arms are bent at the elbows with his hands raised, palms facing the viewer and fingers spread apart. His gestures and open eye indicate fear and perhaps pain. We see the male figure on the right from behind as he ascends the stairs (right leg extended backwards, left leg bent forward). Except for what may be a belt(?) around his waist and a cuff or bracelet at his right wrist, he is nude. The mottled surface of his skin suggests disease or perhaps scales. His hair is curly. His right arm is at his side and he holds two large keys on a ring in his right hand. This last object identifies him as a jailor.

lg.l: The red limb'd Angel siez'd in horror and torment;
The Trump of the last doom; but he could not blow the iron tube!
Thrice he assay'd presumptuous to awake the dead to Judgment.
A mighty Spirit leap'd from the land of Albion,
Nam'd Newton; he siez'd the Trump, & blow'd the enormous blast!
Yellow as leaves of Autumn the myriads of Angelic hosts,
Fell thro' the wintry skies seeking their graves;
Rattling their hollow bones in howling and lamentation.
Then Enitharmon woke nor knew that she had sleptIn Copy K, some of the letters in "Enitharmon" printed very lightly.
And eighteen hundred years were fledIn Copy K, the "f" in "fled" printed very lightly.
As if they had not been
She calld her sons & daughters
To the sports of night,
Within her crystal house;
And thus her song proceeds.
Arise Ethinthus! tho' the earth-worm call:
Let him call in vain;
Till the night of holy shadows
And human solitude is past!

lg.l: Ethinthus queen of waters, how thou shinest in the sky:
My daughter how do I rejoice! for thy children flock around
Like the gay fishes on the wave, when the cold moon drinks the dew.
Ethinthus! thou art sweet as comforts to my fainting soul:
For now thy waters warble round the feet of Enitharmon.
Manathu-Vorcyon! I behold thee flaming in my halls,
Light of thy mothers soul! I see thy lovely eagles round:
Thy golden wings are my delight, & thy flames of soft delusion.
Where is my lureing bird of Eden! Leutha silent love!
Leutha. the many colourd bow delights upon thy wings;
Soft soul of flowers Leutha!
Sweet smiling pestilence! I see thy blushing light;
Thy daughters many changing,
Revolve like sweet perfumes ascending O Leutha silken queen!
Where is the youthful Antamon. prince of the pearly dew,
O Antamon, why wilt thou leave thy mother Enitharmon?
Alone I see thee crystal form,
Floting upon the bosomd air:
With lineaments of gratified desire.
My Antamon the seven churches of Leutha seek thy love,
I hear the soft Oothoon in Enitharmons tents:
Why wilt thou give up womans secrecy my melancholy child?
Between two moments bliss is ripe:
O Theotormon robb'd of joy, I see thy salt tears flow
Down the steps of my crystal house.
Sotha & Thiralatha, secret dwellers of dreamful caves,
Arise and please the horrent fiend with your melodious songs.
Still all your thunders golden hoofd, & bind your horses black.
Orc! smile upon my children!
Smile son of my afflictions.
Arise O Orc and give our mountains joy of thy red light.

She ceas'd, All wer forth at sport beneath the solemn moonLine 33, as originally written, contained these words, "and all went forth to sport," which were changed in the copper to "for All were forth at sport." In Copy K, the "for" and "e" of "were" did not print.
Waking the stars of Urizen with their immortal songs,
That nature felt thro' all her pores the enormous revelry,
Till morning ope'd the eastern gate.Line 36, as originally written, ended with "and the angel trumpet blew!" These five words were erased from the copper plate.
Then every one fled to his station. & Enitharmon wept.
But terrible Orc, when he beheld the morning in the east,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, a nude, muscular male with curly hair stands with legs spread apart, his genitals clearly visible. His left leg is extended to the right, with his left foot on the ground. His right leg is bent at the knee with his foot on one of at least two stone steps. He may be striding to the left. His body faces forward, but his head is turned to the right. His expression is fearful or pained, with mouth slightly open. He may be looking at the flames forming the background of the design or at the child whose left arm he grasps with his lowered left hand. Perhaps the man is the child's father, attempting to rescue the child from the flames. The child would seem to be a gowned female, with long, curly hair. We see her from the side or slightly behind, with her face turned up and to the left; her right arm is drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. Her left leg is extended backward; she may be striding to the left. The nude male carries, over his right shoulder, the limp body of a woman—perhaps the child's mother. She may be nude from the waist up. The man's right arm is raised, bent at the elbow, and embraces the woman around the waist. Her arms and long hair dangle down toward the man's right knee. Her skirt or gown, and one visible foot, dangle behind the man's spread legs. She may be dead or dying. Lower right, on top of the steps, is a fluted and broken pillar.

lg.l: Shot from the heights of Enitharmon;
And in the vineyards of red France appear'd the light of his fury.
The sun glow'd fiery red!
The furious terrors flew around!
On golden chariots raging, with red wheels dropping with blood;
The Lions lash their wrathful tails!
The Tigers couch upon the prey & suck the ruddy tide;
And Enitharmon groans & cries in anguish and dismay,
Then Los arose his head he reard in snaky thunders clad:
And with a cry that shook all nature to the utmost pole,
Call'd all his sons to the strife of blood.
